abstract.p: Mike Kirby letter holds David Thomson's September 17 article asserting that Orson Welles's portrayal of William Randolph Hearst in movie Citizen Kane had more Welles than Hearst in it is old news; photo (S)

block.p: Dramatic front-page news about Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane'' [''Was it Citizen Hearst or Citizen Welles?'' by David Thomson, Sept. 17]! Much-acclaimed movie is more about Welles than Hearst! Did Welles ever say the film was about Hearst? Did an artist worth his salt ever come along who didn't put himself and his character into his work?

Dramatic front-page news about Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane'' [''Was it Citizen Hearst or Citizen Welles?'' by David Thomson, Sept. 17]! Much-acclaimed movie is more about Welles than Hearst! Did Welles ever say the film was about Hearst? Did an artist worth his salt ever come along who didn't put himself and his character into his work?

Mr. Thomson resents, I think, all that old black-and-white populist edginess to ''Citizen Kane.'' So we get revisionism. San Simeon was a beautiful place full of beautiful, elegant people, and Hearst died surrounded by his loved ones. Welles died alone. So what? Welles was an artist and a revolutionary, not an insurance man or a publisher, or a critic, for that matter.
